item.title: Why Business Needs Unified Communications
item.description:
By: John Shepler There was a time when the only way to communicate electronically was with that clunky black phone on your desk. While that phone might still be there, modern technology has made it lighter and brought a wealth of new communication methods. Email, text messages, mobile phone calls, and video chats are now commonplace across various devices like desktops, laptops, tablets, smartphones, and even watches. A significant challenge, particularly in business, is that these platforms and applications don’t always work well together...

item.title: Advantage of Dedicated Cloud Connections
item.description:
Companies of all sizes are increasingly adopting cloud services due to their cost-effectiveness. However, the assumption that a basic internet connection is sufficient for accessing these services is proving to be inaccurate in many situations. While the internet’s widespread availability and affordability make it appealing for WAN services, its security concerns led to the development of VPNs. These secure tunnels encrypt data, allowing remote workers and branch offices to connect securely to corporate networks and transfer sensitive information...

item.title: Why Telephone Wiring is a Thing of the Past
item.description:
The traditional telephone network, known as POTS (Plain Old Telephone Service), utilizes a vast network of thin copper wires connecting buildings to local telephone exchanges. This system, designed solely for analog communication, efficiently serves businesses using traditional phones and low-speed devices like fax machines. Imagine two parallel road systems: high-speed freeways representing computer networks and slower county roads symbolizing the telephone network. Coexisting within the same regions, each serves distinct traffic needs...

item.title: Ethernet Exchange For Miami, Dallas and Los Angeles
item.description:
Carrier Ethernet is emerging as a strong contender to replace the Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN), as evidenced by the increasing number of Ethernet Exchanges that facilitate traffic sharing among carriers. Telx, a prominent interconnection and colocation provider, recently expanded its Ethernet Exchange services to Miami, Dallas, and Los Angeles. Let’s examine the significance of Ethernet Exchange and its impact on the future of international wide-area networking. The PSTN’s global reach and interoperability have contributed to its longstanding success, enabling communication between any two phones worldwide...
